name: Dimensions of the homogeneous component of degree n of the free unital Jordan algebra on 3 generators.
comment: First few terms coincide with A032120 but A032120(8) = 3321. This corresponds to the fact that A032120 gives dimensions of components of the free special Jordan algebra (which follows from Cohn 1959), and 3324 - 3321 = 3 is the dimension of the GL_3-orbit of the so called Glennie identity.
The terms up to a(12) were computed using the Albert nonassociative algebra system.
reference: C. M. Glennie, Identities in Jordan algebras, pp. 307-313 of J. Leech, editor, Computational Problems in Abstract Algebra. Pergamon, Oxford, 1970.

D. P. Jacobs, The Albert nonassociative algebra system: a progress report, pp. 41-44 of Proceedings of the International Symposium on Symbolic and Algebraic Computation, Association for Computing Machinery, New York, NY, USA, 1994.
link: P. M. Cohn, Two embedding theorems for Jordan algebras, Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society, Volume s3-9, Issue 4, October 1959, pp. 503-524.
example: For n = 3, we have a(3)=18 since the following monomials form a basis: x(xx), x(xy), x(xz), x(yy), x(yz), x(zz), y(xx), y(xy), y(xz), y(yy), y(yz), y(zz), z(xx), z(xy), z(xz), z(yy), z(yz), z(zz), these are all commutative nonassociative monomials of degree 3, since the Jordan identity is of degree 4.
author: _Vladimir Dotsenko_, Mar 29 2025

name: Number of reversible strings with n beads of 3 colors.
comment: a(n) is the dimension of the homogeneous component of degree n of the free unital special Jordan algebra on 3 generators (this follows from Cohn 1959). Note that this is no longer true for 4 generators and further. - _Vladimir Dotsenko_, Mar 31 2025
link: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
P. M. Cohn, Two embedding theorems for Jordan algebras, Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society, Volume s3-9, Issue 4, October 1959, pp. 503-524.
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (3,3,-9).
formula: G.f.: (1-6x^2) / ((1-3x)*(1-3x^2)). (End) [Adapted to offset 0 by _Robert A. Russell_, Nov 10 2018]
example: For a(2)=6, the three achiral strings are AA, BB, CC; the three (equivalent) chiral pairs are AB-BA, AC-CA, BC-CB.
In the language of special Jordan algebras, the three latter correspond to the Jordan products (AB+BA)/2, (AC+CA)/2, (BC+CB)/2.
mathematica: CoefficientList[Series[(1-6x^2)/((1-3x) (1-3x^2)), {x, 0, 30}], x] (* _Vincenzo Librandi_, Apr 22 2012 *) (* Adapted to offset 0 by _Robert A. Russell_, Nov 10 2018 *)
program: (Magma) I:=[1, 3, 6]; [n le 3 select I[n] else 3*Self(n-1)+3*Self(n-2)-9*Self(n-3):  n in [1..25]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Apr 22 2012
xref: Cf. A000244 (oriented), A032086(n>1) (chiral), A056449 (achiral), A382233 (free Jordan algebras).
author: _Christian G. Bower_
ext: a(0)=1 prepended by _Robert A. Russell_, Nov 10 2018
